faq.title: Frequently Asked Questions
faq.question1: What's the best time to walk the Camino?
faq.answer1: The best time depends on your chosen route. Generally, April-June and September-October are ideal for most routes.
faq.answer2: Difficulty varies by route. The Camino Francés is beginner-friendly, while the Camino del Norte is more challenging.

tips.title: Senior Pilgrim's Guide
tips.subtitle: Essential tips and advice for travelers 50+ planning their Camino de Santiago journey.

essentialClothing.title: Essential Clothing
essentialClothing.content: Pack 3-4 changes of moisture-wicking clothes, including merino wool base layers. Bring a lightweight rain jacket and pants. Pack one warm layer for evenings.

comfortableFootwear.title: Comfortable Footwear
comfortableFootwear.content: Broken-in hiking boots are essential. Pack 2-3 pairs of moisture-wicking socks and consider bringing camp shoes for evenings.

seniorSpecificItems.title: Senior-Specific Items
seniorSpecificItems.content: Bring a lightweight camping chair, compression socks, extra cushioned insoles, and a small pillow for better sleep comfort.

medicationsHealth.title: Medications & Health
medicationsHealth.content: Pack all medications in original containers, bring a basic first aid kit, and carry copies of prescriptions. Include blister treatment supplies.

electronicsDocuments.title: Electronics & Documents
electronicsDocuments.content: Bring a portable charger, universal adapter, and waterproof phone case. Keep passport, insurance cards, and emergency contacts accessible.

physicalPreparation.title: Physical Preparation
physicalPreparation.content: Start training 3-6 months before your trip. Build up gradually to walking 15-20km with your pack. Focus on strengthening leg muscles and improving cardio.

managingChronicConditions.title: Managing Chronic Conditions
managingChronicConditions.content: Consult your doctor before traveling. Ensure you have enough medication for the entire trip plus extra. Know how to say your conditions in Spanish.

preventingInjuries.title: Preventing Injuries
preventingInjuries.content: Warm up before walking each day. Use trekking poles to reduce joint stress. Take regular breaks and listen to your body.

hydrationNutrition.title: Hydration & Nutrition
hydrationNutrition.content: Drink water regularly, even if not thirsty. Pack electrolyte supplements. Eat regular meals and carry energy snacks.

emergencyContacts.title: Emergency Contacts
emergencyContacts.content: Program local emergency numbers (112 in Spain/Portugal) into your phone. Consider purchasing travel insurance with medical coverage.

personalSafety.title: Personal Safety
personalSafety.content: Walk in groups when possible, especially in urban areas. Inform someone of your daily plans. Trust your instincts about people and situations.

weatherAwareness.title: Weather Awareness
weatherAwareness.content: Check weather forecasts daily. Be prepared for sudden changes in mountain areas. Know signs of heat exhaustion and hypothermia.

moneyValuables.title: Money & Valuables
moneyValuables.content: Use a money belt or hidden pouch. Don't carry large amounts of cash. Keep copies of important documents separate from originals.

navigationSafety.title: Navigation Safety
navigationSafety.content: Always carry a physical map as backup. Download offline maps on your phone. Follow yellow arrows and official waymarks.

spanishCustoms.title: Spanish Customs
spanishCustoms.content: Meals are later than in the US (lunch 2-4pm, dinner 9-11pm). Shops close for siesta (2-5pm). Tipping is not expected but appreciated.

religiousEtiquette.title: Religious Etiquette
religiousEtiquette.content: Dress modestly when visiting churches. Remove hats inside. Be respectful during religious services. Photography may be restricted.

pilgrimTraditions.title: Pilgrim Traditions
pilgrimTraditions.content: Say "Buen Camino" to fellow pilgrims. Respect the credencial (passport) tradition. Be considerate in albergues - wake up quietly.

localInteractions.title: Local Interactions
localInteractions.content: Spanish people are generally warm and helpful. Learn basic Spanish phrases. Be patient with language barriers.

basicGreetings.title: Basic Greetings
basicGreetings.content: Hola (OH-lah) - Hello | Buenos días (BWAY-nos DEE-ahs) - Good morning | Buenas tardes (BWAY-nas TAR-des) - Good afternoon

caminoPhrases.title: Camino Phrases
caminoPhrases.content: Buen Camino (bway-n kah-MEE-no) - Good Way | ¿Dónde está el albergue? (DON-de es-TAH el al-BER-gay) - Where is the hostel?

emergencyPhrases.title: Emergency Phrases
emergencyPhrases.content: Ayuda (ah-YOO-dah) - Help | Necesito un médico (neh-seh-SEE-to oon MEH-di-ko) - I need a doctor | No hablo español (no AH-blo es-pahn-YOHL) - I don't speak Spanish

foodAccommodation.title: Food & Accommodation
foodAccommodation.content: Una cama, por favor (OO-na KAH-ma por fah-VOR) - A bed, please | La cuenta, por favor (la KWAY-n-ta por fah-VOR) - The bill, please

sixMonthsBefore.title: 6 Months Before
sixMonthsBefore.content: Start physical training program. Book flights and first few nights accommodation. Research route and create rough itinerary.

threeMonthsBefore.title: 3 Months Before
threeMonthsBefore.content: Finalize gear purchases and test everything. Get travel insurance. Schedule medical check-up. Start learning basic Spanish.

oneMonthBefore.title: 1 Month Before
oneMonthBefore.content: Confirm all bookings. Pack and weigh your backpack. Arrange for mail/pet care. Download offline maps and apps.

oneWeekBefore.title: 1 Week Before
oneWeekBefore.content: Check weather forecast. Charge all devices. Prepare emergency contact list. Get euros from bank.
